activity-description.narrative: Harmonize national statistics

description.narrative: 1. Number of statistical areas assessed towards compliance with international/EU standards in statistics & policy-makersâ€™ needs. 2. Number of methodologies and toolkits (incl. administrative data sources) developed/ revised from the perspective on international/EU requirements in statistics 3. Number of tools focused and actions on â€œquality of statistical outputâ€ developed to comply with European norms and best practices and to build necessary national capacities 4. Number of statistical surveys designed (complying with international/EU requirements) and carried out to respond to policy-making information needs 5. Number of stat.staff whose capacities to collect & produce quality disaggregated data within statistical sample surveys are built, by topics explored, to make more data available for the research and policy development 6. Number of professional development events carried out and/or training materials (curriculum, manuals, guides) for stat.staff implemented 7. Number of user-friendly statistical outputs developed & disseminated, no of areas covered 8. Level of data usersâ€™ satisfaction with statistical outputs periodically measured and feedback provided 9. Number of data user capacity building initiatives carried out/institutionalized, topics covered, trainees from Gov., CSOs, media whose statistical literacy strengthened 10. Number of policy documents being assisted with M&E tools (stat.indicators, guidance) to contribute to their efficiency and effectiveness 11. Number of research/analytical papers to analyze less explored topics developed on the basis of available statistics in participatory manner

comment.narrative: 1. Statistical areas are not assessed on compliance with EU requirements/standards 2. Moldovan statistical system still suffers from inconsistent methodologies, multiplicity of data sources, fragmented statistical activities in line ministries 3. Data production systems are not fully covered by the international standards related to quaility of statistical outputs and processes 4. Insufficient number and varity of statistical surveys to cover all the information needs 5. Inadequate resources and lack of continuous training and capacity building for statisticians 6. There are limited opportunities for professional development of data producers to comply with actual requirements and international standards in the field 7. Data dissemination covers only core statistical areas and is done through traditional means of communication; 8. Most of indicators are not disaggregated by sex, age, and geographical territory; and even existing disaggregated indicators are often not disseminated and are not easily accessible which do not meet users' needs and satisfaction. 9. Data users have insufficient skills and capacities to efficiently use statistics for participatory policy-making 10. Governmentâ€™s monitoring & evaluation capacities are weak 11. Data/evidence-based analysis is poorly applied to analyze the current situation, develop policies, monitor their implementation and evaluate impact, as well as to assess to what extent Moldova is fulfilling its obligations under economic, social and cultural rights.

1. Comparative analysis of at least 2 statistical surveys undertaken to assess their compliance with EU/international standards and feasibility to measure womenâ€™s entrepreneurship 2. At least one statistical methodology and 1 toolkit developed to measure entrepreneurship from gender perspective responding to national policy framework and data users' needs 3. Feasibility analysis of Harmonized Set of Gender Sensitive Development Indicators in the context of Governmentâ€™s reporting on implementation of National Program on Ensuring Gender Equality and its action plan undertaken; data gaps/difficulties/weaknesses in definitions, sources, processing instruments, quality aspects described to be taken into consideration for drafting of a new National Action Plan 4. Not applicable in 2015 5. Knowledge and capacities of at least 5 statisticians to produce new disaggregated data on measurement of womenâ€™s entrepreneurship built 6. At least one event organized for statisticians from the East Europe and Central Asia on presentation of UNECE training toolkit for users of gender statistics (in collaboration with UNECE) 7. Results of gender-sensitive statistical surveys disseminated in at least one user-friendly statistical publication (â€˜Women & Menâ€™), and one e-application responding to data usersâ€™ needs 8. Not applicable in 2014 9. Knowledge and abilities of at least 50 data users (Women NGOs, public authorities), strengthened within at least 2 tailored trainings on the use of gender statistics for advocacy and lobbying, evidence-based monitoring and justification of new policies; and within one national dialogue/consultation among policy-makers and statisticians on localizing of SDGs (Goal 5 and other) 10. National strategy on development of statistical system developed; Recommendations on improvement of Governmentâ€™s M&E activity developed to tackle gender equality and womenâ€™s entrepreneurship 11.1. A series of at least 5 thematic data-based analytical briefs related to the

1. Comparative analysis of 2 stat. surveys (on business and Labour Force Survey) plus other 4 administrative sources undertaken assessing their compliance with EU/international standards and feasibility to measure womenâ€™s entrepreneurship 2. One statistical methodology and 1 toolkit developed to measure entrepreneurship from gender perspective responding to national policy framework and data users' needs 3. Feasibility analysis of Harmonized Set of Gender Sensitive Development Indicators in the context of Governmentâ€™s reporting on implementation of National Program on Ensuring Gender Equality and its action plan (until 2015) undertaken; gaps in data, definitions, sources, processing instruments, quality aspects described to be taken into consideration for drafting of a new National Action Plan 2016-20; 4. Not applicable in 2015 5. Knowledge and capacities of 9 statisticians to produce new disaggregated data on measurement of womenâ€™s entrepreneurship built 6. One event organized for 44 statisticians from the East Europe and Central Asia on presentation of UNECE training toolkit for users of gender statistics (in collaboration with UNECE) 7. Structure of e-application designed to disseminate gender-sensitive stat. data in a visual format to facilitate the data users' understanding of gender statistics 8. Not applicable in 2014 9. Knowledge and abilities of 140 data users (Women NGOs, gender focal points, CPAs, academia, business), strengthened within 3 tailored trainings (on use of gender statistics for advocacy, lobbying, evidence-based monitoring and justification of new policies, and for media communication), 2 national workshops (on localizing of SDGs, women entrepreneurship measurement) 10. National strategy on development of statistical system developed and publicly presented (49 users, 29 statisticians); Recommendations on improvement of Governmentâ€™s M&E activity developed to tackle gender equality and womenâ€™s entrepreneurship 11.1. A series of 5 themati

1. At least 3 stat. areas assessed towards compliance with international standards to enable the measurement of certain targets under SDGs agenda, including through gender perspective. 2. At least 3 sets of statistical methodologies, questionnaires and software developed to enable data collection in 3 areas which are relevant to SDGs (Goal 10 - Inequality, Goal 5 - Men/Women Entrepreneurship and ICT activity of population) 3. N/A 4. At least 3 statistical surveys designed and piloted in 3 areas which are relevant to SDGs (Goal 10 - Inequality, Goal 5 - Men/Women Entrepreneurship and ICT activity of population) 5. At least 4 statisticians and 5 interviewers benefit of on-the-job training on collection or production of disaggregated data in at least 2 areas (inequality and ICT) 6. N/A 7. One e-solution on gender statisticsâ€™ visual dissemination developed and operationalized to improve data use/application for policy making 8. One up-to-date report to assess the usersâ€™ satisfaction and information needs developed and presented to the public 9. At least 2 capacity building activities carried out for data users (policy-makers, CSOs, etc.) on at least 2 topics of statistics 10. M&E tools (statistical indicators and methodological guidance) developed to support at least 2 policy documents; Technical guidance and conceptual support provided to at least 3 UN/DP Projects to enable and facilitate the M&E under UNPF 11. 10 profiles on vulnerable groups of women disseminated (in at least 3 formats) making sex

description.narrative: Improving the quality of Moldovan democracy through parliamentary and electoral support
Parliamentâ€™s institutional capacity, transparency and effectiveness of legislative structures, systems and processes developed and knowledge of legislators and staff expanded.
Further strengthening of CEC and CCET professionalism of electoral administrators through trainings and support

1. Centre for Continuous Electoral Training has improved capacities and training curricula, methodologies and materials, as well as a pool of certified electoral trainers (at least 40) available 2. Electoral reforms supported through provision of expertise and facilitation of dialog and consultations with Civil Society Organisations and general public on the reform actions 3. Political parties finance transparency improved through expertise and training for the implementation of the law on political party financing 4. Central Electoral Commission has a modern population register with an addresses system and inter-operable with other key state registers

comment.narrative: 1. Centre for Continuous Electoral Training lacks basic capacity to organize and conduct electoral training as this is a new institution: lack of training modules, materials, curricula; lack of a pool of professional trainers 2. Electoral reform needed in the areas of electoral administration; electoral systems; voter registration, as indicated in several OSCE/ODIHR reports 3. Law on political party financing absent 4. The State and Central Electoral Commission lacks a modern population register with an address system, integrated with other key state registers

1. Center for Continuous Electoral Training provides training to 20,000 electoral administrators ahead of the local elections 2. Population registration system concept developed 3. Political parties financing reform implementation supported through expertise and training for parties and Central Electoral Commission on monitoring of financing. 4. At least 2 e-registers relevant for the Votersâ€™ Register developed and inter-operable

1. Center for Continuous Electoral Training (CCET) provided training to 11225 electoral administrators ahead of the General Local Elections 2015. Capacities of Gagauz lower level EMB strengthened though trainings delivered by CCET. 2. Preparations for development of population registration concept and support to Civil Status Service (CSS) - ongoing. Strategy for the institutional modernization of the CSS and optimization of business processes â€“ ongoing. 3. Political parties financing reform implementation supported through international expertise. The Central Electoral Commission and political partiesâ€™ capacities strengthened during a BRIDGE workshop on Political Financing. 4. Address system draft law finalized after a large consultations with stakeholders. Amendments to other legal acts related to adoption of Address System Law prepared. Technical specifications of Address Register IT system drafted. 5. Technical specifications for other registers drafted (Ministry of Defense) 6. Semantic interoperability in the process of development. Interoperability legal and regulatory framework drafted.

title.narrative: Project Document_Low Emission Capacity Building Programme

description.narrative: Strengthened national institutional and technical capacity contributes to an improved National GHG Inventory System; the implementation of NAMAs in the context of national development; and their monitoring, verification and progress reporting

The Clima-East Programme is a partnership on biodiversity and climate change intending to demonstrate that ecosystems can have a strong, positive and cost-efficient effect on climate change mitigation and adaptation.

The project will demonstrate a natural resource management model in the pastures and forest of Moldova which increases ecosystems capacity to sequester carbon while at the same time retain biodiversity and economic values.

1. Number of communities and hectares of pastures managed according to the pasture management plans. 2. Number of hectares of community forests managed according to the forest management plans. 3. Number of hectares of pastures land restored using economic valuable species. 4. Number of hectares of community degraded lands afforested using native species as lead species (oak, linden, field maple, ash, elm, cherry, poplar, willow). 5. Monitoring system in place consisting of a) ecological integrity of the grassland ecosystem (richness and density of indicator species populations, such as indicator species (Festuca valesiaca, Bothriochloa ischaemum, Stipa capillata, Poa bulbosa, Poa angustifolia, Artemisia austriaca)). b) volume of biomass growth for forest ecosystems c) carbon dividends 6. Number of people involved in the capacity building and awareness activities at the national, regional and local levels. Increased level of understanding about sustainable grassland, forest management and climate change risks.

comment.narrative: 1. No communities (0 ha) with pasture management plans in place. 2. 0 ha of community forests with management plans 3. Degraded pasture on the most of the park territory 4. No degraded lands afforested on the park territory. 5. No monitoring system in place. 6. Insufficient trainings and awareness in sustainable grassland and forest management

1. 18 pasture management plans for 5890 ha of pasture broadly consulted with pasture owners and users and put in practice 2. Forest management plans provided to beneficiaries and appropriate guidance for their implementation ensured on 1,392 ha 3. Monitoring of pasture restoration grants ensured for their proper and timely implementation on 472 ha of allocated lands. 4. Completion, management, guarding and protection of forest plantations established on 150 ha of degraded lands in order to ensure the 78% overall survival of plantings according to the forestry technical norms for Orhei region. LPAâ€™s participation ensured in plantations guarding and protection. 5. Keep up with the latest carbon monitoring tools, practices at the global and regional level in order to update the developed Carbon Monitoring Database, under the project. 6. A training programme in sustainable grassland and forest management developed and delivered for local communities, farmers, leaders of farmer association and other key groups; exchange of information on successful practices in pasture restoration and management in cooperation with other relevant initiatives ensured at both national and regional level

1. Draft version of pasture management plans developed, broadly consulted with pasture owners and users and submitted to local communities for approval 2. Forest management plans for 1,392 ha provided to beneficiaries and appropriate guidance for their implementation ensured through relevant workshops, meetings and local events 3. Pasture restoration grants monitoring on 472 ha of allocated lands ensured through field visits and trainings 4. 150 ha of degraded lands afforested, and all management, care, guarding and protection works and activities performed in time in order to ensure the 78% overall survival of plantings 5. The Carbon Monitoring Database updated according to the latest developments in the field developed and best practices disseminated during the training programme on sustainable grassland and forest management

1. Implementation of the pasture and forestry management plans supported through explanatory meetings and recommendations provided. 2. A detailed assessment of the real socio-economic benefits (for LPAs and land users themselves) performed and innovative incentive measures (including financial) proposed to support sustainable approaches for land management. 3. Monitoring of pasture restoration grants ensured for their proper and timely implementation on 472 ha of allocated lands. 4. Completion, management, guarding and protection of forest plantations established on 150 ha of degraded lands in order to ensure the 78% overall survival of plantings according to the forestry technical norms for Orhei region. LPAâ€™s participation ensured in plantations guarding and protection. 5. A training programme in sustainable grassland and forest management developed and delivered for local communities, farmers, leaders of farmer association and other key groups; exchange of information on successful practices in pasture restoration and management in cooperation with other relevant initiatives ensured at both national and regional level

description.narrative: The project will support Moldova with the National Adaptation Planning process which fosters the system and capacities for medium-to long term adaptation planning and budgeting.

The goal of the project is to ensure that Moldova has a system and capacities in place for medium- to long term adaptation planning and budgeting, with the aim to reduce vulnerability of population and key sectors to the impacts of climate change.
The project seeks to increase national ownership and leadership for disaster resilience through improved coordination capacities, awareness and knowledge and innovative technology transfer.

Increasing national ownership and leadership for disaster resilience. Support shall be provided to development of the National DRM Strategy, to mainstreaming DRR in educational programs and piloting innovative DRM measures on the local level.

activity-description.narrative: Piloting Local Government Self Assessment Tool (LGSAT), mainstreaming City Resilience Measures into development planning and piloting DRR innovation tools.
ToT for Civil Protection Personnel and NGO's representatives on Community Disaster Risk Management; Capacity Building and support for Civil Protection and Emergency Situations Service

description.narrative: 1. Number of training programmes for electoral administrators gender mainstreamed. 2. Percentage of women members of CEC and of District and Precinct level electoral commissions 3. Number of voter education campaigns targeting specific groups of voters carried out before parliamentary and local elections 4. Number of meetings between Members of Parliament and women from rural and urban areas, especially vulnerable women, organized 5. Number of women MPs trained 6. Number of women councilors trained

comment.narrative: 1. Training programmes for electoral administrators not gender mainstreamed 2. 36% women in leadership positions of district electoral commissions 3. No particular focus on women, youth and vulnerable groups in the previous voter registration and education campaigns 4. No targeted meetings of Members of Parliament with women and their organizations. 5. Newly elected women MPs did not receive initial training

1. Achieved. 4 training modules of CCET for 2015 local elections gender mainstreamed; 2. Achieved. For 2015 local elections, women held 53% senior management positions in District Electoral Commissions, and 85% in Precinct Electoral Commissions . 3. Achieved. 3 voter education campaigns targeting women from vulnerable groups, including women with disabilities, Roma and other ethnic minority women conducted in 27 localities in 12 districts prior to local elections involving directly 10,816 beneficiaries, including 9,915 women from vulnerable groups 4. Achieved. A number of 5 regional parliamentary forums giving the possibility to 230 people, including 206 women from vulnerable groups to raise their issues with MPs facilitated 5. Achieved. Capacities of 13 newly elected women MPs, as well as of the 9 women MPs with former mandates enhanced in areas of communications, media, including social media and public image 6. Achieved. 108 women from 9 pilot districts newly elected as local and district councilors enhanced capacities in areas of local council functioning, fostering gender equality in local development agenda, finance, fundraising and communications

1. Project overall target achieved in 2015 2. At least 2 women members of CEC 3. Project overall target achieved in 2015 4. At least 5 regional parliamentary forums bringing constituents from vulnerable groups, particularly women, and MPs facilitated 5. Project overall target achieved in 2015 6. At least 100 women from 5 pilot districts enhanced capacities in areas of local council functioning, fostering gender equality in local development agenda, finance, fundraising and communications
